title: (x) New Yorker - Irvin {Mike Y}
content:

comments.content:
Oh, and since MyFonts lets you test drive FF fonts now, here is FF New Yorker so you can see them all.   
 ![FF New Yorker sample](http://web.archive.org/web/20141004120221im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/29042.gif)

You're right Mike. There are a lot of interpretations that I overlooked.   
I am also told that the actual font used by the magazine (maybe   
not for the masthead itself but when they are doing illustrations   
with similar type) was commissioned to Monotype and is called   
"Irvin". It matches perfectly but is assumedly not for retail.

Hah, just now got your first post via email notification, Mike.   
The system seems a little wonky right now.

That's almost it. The real font is called "Irvin" after Rea Irvin the original New Yorker art director. The main difference between the fonts like FF New Yorker, Manhattan and Upper West Side, which are all Irvin look-alikes, is the Q. See the following sample scanned from McGrew's "American Metal Typefaces of the Twentieth Century"   
 ![Irvin Sample](http://web.archive.org/web/20141004120221im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/29037.gif)   
   
The next two samples are Manhattan from Franklin Type Founders (at Precision Type) and Upper West Side from Intecsas (also at Precision Type). You'll notice that only the Intecsas font tried to get the lettering right.   
 ![Franklin Manhattan](http://web.archive.org/web/20141004120221im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/29038.gif)   
 ![Intecsas Upper West Side](http://web.archive.org/web/20141004120221im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/29039.gif)
